name: GCN-4A "Titan"
description: The Titan is the first tier-4 gravity constructor and the first surface robot built around full plasma arc disaggregation — a fundamentally different relationship between machine and rock. Rather than attacking the face with a directed point source, the Titan deploys a bank of six transferred-arc plasma electrodes arranged in a linear array across a 4 m working face. Each electrode operates at 12 kW, and the inter-electrode plasma curtain covers the full face at once, raising the near-surface layer to disaggregation temperature in seconds. The rock does not simply melt: the arc temperature (12,000–15,000 K) exceeds the Leidenfrost point for most silicate and oxide compounds, causing gas-phase dissociation with minimal energy lost to bulk heating of excavated material. Products are swept into a high-velocity pneumatic riser at 900 kg/hr sustained throughput — more than twice the Archon's best rate. Separated feed enters a cascade magnetic-electrostatic process train that routes ilmenite, olivine, pyroxene, and feldspar fractions to separate holding bins for downstream use. Construction is handled by a separate 12-axis cable-suspended gantry robot spanning a 20 m work envelope, carrying a high-deposition-rate electron beam wire deposition head and a multi-material regolith casting shuttle. The Titan can erect a pressurised habitat module shell in approximately 72 hours of continuous operation.
